    Sai Kanth Dacha

    PhD Candidate at University of Maryland | Nonlinear Optics | Multimode Fibers

    • Washington, D.C. Metro Area

    Interests

    Photography

    I am an avid photographer. I own the Canon EOS 1200D DSLR with the 18-55 mm and 55-250 mm lenses. The fascinatingly beautiful campus that IIT Madras was, it proved to be paradise for the wildlife photographer and nature lover in me. I maintain an online portfolio of my pictures on 500px and Instagram.

    Writing

    Lately, I have taken to writing down my thoughts on issues that interest me. I find that writing helps me develop better clarity in my thoughts and opinions, and helps me think more critically. As my PhD supervisor would probably agree, I have some ways to go when it comes to writing well. But I hope to sustain this habit and improve. You can find my writing here on Medium.

    Biking

    I am passionate about endurance biking. I have taken part in a number of 100km+ rides at IIT Madras and Chennai as part of various cycling clubs at the institute and city levels. Back there, I rode the Rockrider 5.0 mountain bike. After moving to the US, I purchased the 2017 model of the Kona Jake Cyclocross. Although I have not been able to ride as actively as I did back at IIT, I have nevertheless gone on a bunch of solo long rides here in the DC area. My favorites include the ride to Baltimore and back, and the one to Annapolis and back. They are both great places to visit, and I highly recommend the trails and roads leading to these places from DC!

    Reading

    I enjoy reading, be it over a cup of coffee or when I am traveling. For the past year or two, I have been primarily reading non-fiction. I am currently reading ‘Good Economics for Hard Times’, written by Nobel Prize winners Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo. Given my recent interest in economics, another book I have lined up right after this is Raghuram Rajan’s latest ‘The Third Pillar’. If physics doesn’t work out for me, I would enjoy working in economics! When not reading, I enjoy spending that time instead on nerdy YouTube channels and podcasts, unless of course I decide to binge watch a TV show!

    Chess

    From the Indian version of the game “chaturanga” to becoming a benchmark test for artificial intelligence developers, chess has survived for thousands of years, through periods of time where humanity saw immense change. I only started playing a couple of years ago. There are few things more satisfying than a well-played game of chess.
